clinical_study.brief_title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia in Euthymic Bipolar Disorder
clinical_study.official_title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia in Euthymic Bipolar Disorder: a Randomized Controlled Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

clinical_study.source: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

brief_summary.textblock: Patients with bipolar disorder suffer from sleep disturbances, even in euthymic phases. Changes in sleep are frequent signs of a new episode of (hypo)mania or depression. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia is an effective treatment for primary insomnia, but has not been introduced to patients with bipolar disorder. The aim is to compare cognitive behavioral therapy added to 'treatment as usual' with just 'treatment as usual'. The investigators hypothesize that cognitive behavioral therapy will improve quality of sleep, stabilize minor mood variations and prevent new mood episodes in euthymic patients with bipolar disorder and insomnia.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in quality of sleep at 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: As assessed by the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI)

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in quality of sleep at 6 months follow-up
primary_outcome.time_frame: 6 months from end of treatment phase
primary_outcome.description: As assessed by the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI)

secondary_outcome.measure: Variation in sleep registration from baseline to 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Comparing registrations of sleep by sleep diaries, actigraphs and polysomnography.

secondary_outcome.measure: Variation in sleep registration from baseline to 6 months follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Comparing registrations of sleep by sleep diaries, actigraphs and polysomnography.

arm_group.description: Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is a multicomponent treatment consisting of sleep restriction therapy, psychoeducation about sleep, stimulus control, stabilizing circadian rhythm and challenging beliefs and perception of sleep.
Treatment as usual (TAU) consists of pharmacological and supportive psychosocial treatment according to the needs of the patient.

intervention.description: CBT-I will be given during 3-6 sessions according to need by two therapists being either psychiatrists or psychologists with clinical experience in CBT-I.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Fulfilling criteria for SCID-1-verified bipolar I or II disorder
- Euthymic, as defined by Montgomery Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) not higher than eleven, and Young Mania Rating scale (YMRS) not higher than five.
- Fulfilling DSM-IV criteria for primary insomnia or insomnia related to another mental disorder, as assessed by the Insomnia Interview Schedule (IIS).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Being or having been in a defined affective episode the last month before inclusion
- Hospitalization in the last two months before inclusion
- Working night shifts
- Sleep apnea
- Medical conditions incompatible with participation.
- Inability to cooperate in the 3-week initial phase before randomization.
